comment_text: This looks like it's mostly an issue of expectations.  "Build next to the shore, it won't flood."   In places like the Gulf of Maine and Bay of Fundy, with tides that range between one and six meters regularly, and considerably more during storms, you just don't build where water is likely to go.  This is going to require a slow reversal of shore-building trends in these places with "flooding problems", with construction along the shore forbidden unless it's going to be high enough above the high water marks.

A spring tide occurs during new and full moon (three space objects in a line). A neap tide, seven days after a spring tide, refers to a period of moderate tides when the sun and moon are at right angles to each other.
A proxigean spring tide (also known as a perigean spring tide) is a tide that occurs three or four times per year when the Erath-moon-system is close to another wilst a spring tide (when the Sun, the Moon, and Earth are nearly aligned every two weeks) is happening. This tide usually adds only a couple of inches to normal spring tides.
Mind that the moon creates not only the classic fluent tide with the same effect but aswell on the other side of earth (called inertia?).

Is this effect why the tidal Bohr (I hope I spelled it right) of the Bay of Fundy (Nova Scotia, Canada) is supposed to cause a huge rush of water based on the tide?

As a kid we went to observe it once in the 1970s. We could see huge sandy mud flats, and a very tall wooden dock structure. Barnacles quite high up on the dock showed that water levels were very high indeed (I was only 8, so my memory likely has changed over time). When the time for the tide came, we expected a huge wave... and were very disappointed by a tiny waves of only a few inches. We left disappointed.

Is the Tidal Bohr a real phenomenon, or were we hoodwinked?

Liquids don't have friction.  Solids have friction.  Liquids are often involved with solids having friction with other solids, but friction and how it effects the solids involved are exclusive to the solid materials unless the friction is intense enough to cause a solid  to change state. In such circumstances friction may likley not be your main concern.  A solid does not cause friction upon a gas or a liquid because these states of matter conform to the solid shapes surrounding. This is why friction only applys to solids. No big deal physics is getting old and probably will retire soon anyway.

Video concludes at the end suggesting that this phenomenon is global in scale when it's clearly local. I agree with another commenter, this is a little click-baity. Not so much an issue with ships, but with poor port planning. Still an interesting consequence of ignoring open channel fluid dynamics and example of engineers failing to consider less obvious factors. Like the skyscraper death-ray.

Higher tides also mean more saltwater coming in, intruding farther upstream and changing freshwater ecosystems to brackish or saltwater ones.

Jetties at inlets to maintain the channel at the mouth of a river have long been problematic because they interfere with near-shore drift. The beach on one side of the inlet builds up because the jetty traps sand there while on the other side the beach keeps eroding away because the sand isn't getting replaced. Charleston Harbor's jetties caused an entire island (Morris Island) to become a sandbar because they blocked near-shore drift and also funneled the silt outflow from the Ashley and Cooper Rivers farther out to sea.

So they've completely forgotten basic 19th century era harbor planning.  This has nothing to do with tidal forces, it's simply inadequate drainage infrastructure.  When expanding a harbor, the dredged material was used to build levy banks which were reinforced to become wharves, while the surrounding areas were buried/raised to prevent drainage issues - you can see the buried buildings at virtually every 19th century port where this was practiced.  How did engineers manage to forget this basic fact?
